sailpoint.integration

Class RestServlet

  • java.lang.Object
    • javax.servlet.GenericServlet
      • javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet
        • sailpoint.integration.RestServlet
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, javax.servlet.Servlet, javax.servlet.ServletConfig
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    IntegrationServlet

    public abstract class RestServlet
extends javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet
    An HttpServlet to handle REST requests.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • service

        public void service(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                    javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse response)
             throws java.io.IOException,
                    javax.servlet.ServletException
        Many browsers and HTTP clients do not support PUT and DELETE methods so simulate these with a request parameter.

        Since we don't have any put/delete methods this isn't very useful but I wanted to get the mechanism in place in case we have some someday (and we can at least return the right error message).

        This also performs authentication (if enabled) before the request is dispatched to the appropriate method.

        Overrides:
        service in class javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        javax.servlet.ServletException

      • getCredentials

        protected java.lang.String[] getCredentials(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req)
                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Return the credentials pulled from the request in a two-element String array with the first element being the username and the second element being the password. These are pulled from the Authorization header or special request parameters.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • shouldAuthenticate

        protected boolean shouldAuthenticate(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
        Subclasses can override this method to disable authentication checks for certain requests. An example is if the servlet has a resource that performs authentication and returns more detailed information for failed responses, such as "password expired", "account locked" etc...
        Parameters:
        req - The HttpServletRequest being processed.
        Returns:
        True if authentication should be performed for the given request. This returns true by default.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • performAuthentication

        protected abstract boolean performAuthentication(java.lang.String username,
                                                 java.lang.String password)
                                          throws java.lang.Exception
        Perform authentication for the given username and password. Subclasses should implement this according to the authentication mechanism that is available. For instance, this can authenticate with a user store that is a part of the application, or could simply read usernames and passwords out of a properties file or from the servlet init parameters.
        Parameters:
        username - The username to authenticate.
        password - The password of the given user.
        Returns:
        True if authentication was successful, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • parseURL

        public java.util.List parseURL(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Convert a URL into a list of path elements. The URL must have this form:

        http://ipaddr:port/identityiq/service/el1/el2...?args

        We will ignore the first element of the path since "identityiq" isn't always used and "service" has to be there or else we wouldn't match the servlet-mapping. getPathInfo() nicely give us the remainder. Query args will already be accessible with HttpServletRequest.getParameter and getParameterMap

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
